video.title: Learn JSON - Full Crash Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn everything you need to know about JSON in 10 minutes. 

You will learn:
- what JSON is, 
- why JSON is important, 
- what JSON is used for, 
- the syntax of JSON, 
- and see multiple examples of JSON. 

JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is the most popular data representation format, and is one of the most important, and easiest concepts you can learn in programming. It allows you to create APIs, config files, and structured data. We will be covering all of the terminology, and going through live examples of all the different JSON types.

Tutorial created by Web Dev Simplified. Check out their channel for more great content: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCFbNIlppjAuEX4znoulh0Cw

Twitter: https://twitter.com/DevSimplified

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Web Dev Simplified

topLevelComment.author: Thiago Silva Farias
topLevelComment.text: Just an observation.  On 9:45 you used backticks ( ` ) also known as a grave accent (what is not the same of a single quote). This is called Template literals, both quotes and apostrophes can be used safely without any sort of extra escaping or consideration. Template literals provide multi-line support as well.

topLevelComment.author: femaledeer
topLevelComment.text: It seems like copying the Json code without quotes and copying the json code with quotes and then parsing it, accomplished the same, so I don’t understand why you would want to copy it as a string.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: The reason I copied it as a string is because if you read the JSON from a file, or an API it will be returned as a string and not an object. I wanted to show how to parse JSON that is in a string format since that is the most common way you will interact with JSON.

replies.author: Enrish123
replies.text: I see. Thank you :)

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: The point of the video is not to learn JavaScript but instead to learn JSON. JSON has a different syntax than JavaScript objects so I had to show how to make JSON in its own file. I then copied it over to show that JSON can be integrated easily with JavaScript and how you can convert from strings to objects.

topLevelComment.author: Manish Singh Bisht
topLevelComment.text:
At 9:44
Why only back-ticks? With quotes(single and double both)  variable didn't get detected as string, but JS use quotes for string type objects...that's a little confusing

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: @Manish Singh Bisht no problem. Let me know if you run into anything confusing when you are reading. I'll be happy to help.

replies.author: Manish Singh Bisht
replies.text:
@Web Dev Simplified ohh...I get it now!
 For a string to span  multiple lines and to wrapping up other strings, a third way is needed, that is with backticks(or Apostrophe). 
That's why single & double quotes didn't work, due to nesting of strings.
I'll read more about it...

Thanks for your video and the quick answer!

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Back ticks are a third way to define strings in JavaScript and it allows you to use single and double qoutes in the string as well as variables inside the string if they are wrapped by ${}. Lastly it allows you to wrap a string onto multiple lines in the code. I use back ticks a lot since it makes defining complex strings so much easier. I recommend reading up on it and string interpolation in JavaScript.

topLevelComment.author: d74g0n
topLevelComment.text: 2:32 "undefined" ?

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Undefined is actually not a valid JSON value even though it is valid JavaScript. You would need to use null instead of undefined for JSON.

topLevelComment.author: Esra Erimez
topLevelComment.text: By the way, YAML 1.2 *is* a superset of JSON.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: @Esra Erimez that's really cool. Thanks for sharing. I've learned so much from smart people like you since I started making videos. I love it.

replies.author: Esra Erimez
replies.text:
JSON syntax is a basis of YAML version 1.2, which was promulgated with the express purpose of bringing YAML "into compliance with JSON as an official subset"
From: http://yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html
"The primary objective of this revision is to bring YAML into compliance with JSON as an official subset."

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Interesting. I I have been using YAML for awhile now and didn't realize it could parse JSON as well. The syntax is so dissimilar I just assumed they were differnt.

topLevelComment.author: Γιώργος Γεωργίου
topLevelComment.text: Very interesting introductory video. How can i link and call an external json file instead of importing into the .html file?

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: This would be done most likely through an API which will return JSON data. Another way would be to tell your server to set a JavaScript variable before rendering the page so you have access to the JSON on the client.

topLevelComment.author: christooss
topLevelComment.text:
So is JSON basically Python Dictionary in a implemented JS file?
Learning both Web development and Python so I don't know how much these two things differ.

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text:
JSON is just a data format which is used to store data in a uniform way. A dictionary is another way to store data but it does not support complex data structures as well as JSON and is not easy to send or parse that data other than in the program it was written for.

JSON is used mostly to send data between applications while dictionaries are mostly for within an application.

topLevelComment.author: Predo
topLevelComment.text: Awesome video! Everything is comprehensive and It's a good start for beginners. 'Looking forward to next videos ;)

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Thanks. I try to make all my videos focused on giving as much quality content as possible without being needlessly complicated.

topLevelComment.author: Robin sam
topLevelComment.text: Could have included JSON.stringify explanation too...Good work..!!

replies.author: Web Dev Simplified
replies.text: Thanks! JSON.stringify is a really useful function, especially for debugging, but I wanted to keep this course as light as possible on the JavaScript, since the main purpose was to learn JSON. I only included the JavaScript section to showcase how JSON can be easily used in any language, especially JavaScript.
